comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
See comments etc here for discussion of fountain and links to other images - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4272331133/] EDIT: Or, if you can't be bothered, I've extracted them for you ... 1868-1881 [see thumbnail no. 100 in album] by John Lane Mullins (compiler) 1870-1875 by American & Australian Photographic Company 1879 by Charles Bayliss 1880 by Richards & Co. ca. 1879-1884 [see thumbnail no. 17 in album] by August Tronier Regarding the fountain, built 1866, destroyed during construction of the Cahill Expressway:
Terracotta and stone drinking fountain at the end of Fig Tree Avenue, outside the main gate to the Upper Garden, of what is now the Phillip Precinct of the Domain. This was the only drinking fountain in the Domain, and it was 'improved' in 1897 so that stock would not drink from the same basin.
from The Wishing Tree by Edwin Wilson, Kangaroo Press, Kenthurst NSW, 1992, p. 125.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: William Hetzer's Stereoscopic Views of Sydney & Environs - pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/42415/20060801-0000/macleay/www.us... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/] You've seen the work of Hetzer before - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/4091217376/] See the new comment I've left.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] John Degotardi knew Hetzer - "At the request of W. Kirchner, Esq., Consul for Prussia and Hamburgh, we, the undersigned, investigated the complaints of a number of immigrants per William Kirchner, Captain Henke, stated in a petition to his Excellency the Governor-General, &c., and found ...
B. Frerichs, chairman Ed Lotze W. Hetzer John Degotardi H. J. A. Wagner, sec. pro. tem.
Sydney, September 13th, 1858." - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13017438

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Degotardi and Hetzer also both served on the committee of the New South Wales Leichhardt Search Fund, which organized a concert in August 1865 where a CDV of the explorer (very probably this one by Hetzer of Leichhardt's cast, dated 8 July 1865) would be handed out to the ladies attending. See: Empire Saturday 12 August 1865, p. 1, 5th column - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/64142526

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Aha! Degotardi took over Hetzer's studio. Tuesday 23 April 1867 was his first day as a commercial studio photographer. The Sydney Morning Herald, Thursday 18 April 1867, p. 8, 2nd column - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13142539

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Goodness, you have had a busy night! There is a snippet of info in the PhM blurb on the Macquarie Place/Street photo, which says - "In 1867, Hetzer left Australia and returned to England, auctioning off his photographic equipment, and about 3500 registered negatives, to the photographer Joseph[sic] Degotardi." from.ph/69025

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Sir William Macarthur, who was taught to use a camera by Hetzer, tells a humourous story of Hetzer and of the ordeal for sitters of the long exposure -
"One day," he says, "an old lady from the country was sitting before Hetzer's camera. Mrs. Hetzer, whose name was Teckla [sic - Thekla], helped in the studio and sensitised the plate in the darkroom while her husband posed the sitter. When the old lady was ready for the plate, Hetzer called out to his wife, 'Teckla! Teckla!' whereupon the nervous sitter jumped up in terror and exclaimed 'For heaven's sake don't tickle me, sir, I can't Stand any more!'"
from The Story of the Camera in Australia by Jack Cato (Melbourne : Georgian House, 1955), p. 17.

comment.author: 56925482@N07
comment._content:
Look at the wooden seat the lady is sitting on to the left of the drinking fountain. This was the Art Nouveau period of the world and Australia who are keeping up with the period  featuring a very heavy thick wooden seat with lovely flowing lines and curves.
You can still buy this type of outdoor Garden furniture today one hundred and thirty four years later same style.
I thought I might just add my 2 bobs worth of what I noticed also. cheers

comment._content: Make that 11 out of 60 ... Digital ID: 15344_a044_000046.jpg The "Bridge of Singleton" - Great Northern Railway. / N.S.Wales. / 1866. handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/105701

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: This one from the album could be by Degotardi, also 1866, and like Hetzer's, also exhibited at the 1866 Intercolonial Exhibition in Melbourne - "Interior of the Machine shop, with labourers working on machinery." Digital ID: 15344_a044_000030.jpg [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8596549952/]Machine shop - Government dry dock, Sydney, Australia search.slv.vic.gov.au/primo_library/libweb/action/dlDispl... And this one is almost certainly by Degotardi - "Includes the Gasworks chimney bearing a plaque reading 'GASWORKS 1840' and a gasometer made of iron in the foreground. Balmain can be seen across the water." Digital ID: 15344_a044_000020.jpg [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8595447733/]Gas Light Company's Head Station on the Eastern Shore of Darling Harbour / the back ground shewing portions of the Town of Balmain. / Sydney. N.S.Wales. 1866. search.slv.vic.gov.au/primo_library/libweb/action/dlDispl...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Both Hetzer and Degotardi, along with several other photographers, were awarded medals at the Intercolonial Exhibition of 1866-7 "for a beautiful collection of views of Sydney and its neighbourhood." - The Argus, Thursday 14 February 1867, p. 2 [4th column, 5th paragraph] - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/5786000/218040

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Another photo from the album can be attributed to John Degotardi senior - Digital ID: 15344_a044_000003.jpg Entrance to Port Jackson N.S.W. looking east from Georges Head, c.1867-1870 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemdetailpaged.aspx?itemid=421007 Note: it could still have been taken in 1866 and printed later on a card with his post-1867 George Street address. And could this be Digital ID: 15344_a044_000053.jpg? Triumphal Arch, Circular Quay, Sydney. On the occasion of the public landing of H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh, 1868 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=839958 ... and this Digital ID: 15344_a044_000055.jpg? Arch, corner Oxford [i.e. Liverpool] and College Street, Sydney, Sydney, 1868 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=931825

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The following photographs also appear in [New Zealand, Hobart, Melbourne and Sydney / from an album of photographs with the inscription] "Colonel Trevor, 14th Regiment, November 10th, 1869", and have been attributed to John Degotardi senior by the State Library of NSW - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=421465 - "Nos. 76,79 & 94 attributed to John Degotardi, 287 George St., Sydney from: Photograph album : Sydney, Newcastle and Bathurst views (Mitchell Library PXB 258)" See page 9 in album view ... Digital ID: 15344_a044_000006.jpg [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8579018794/]76. Sydney Harbour [i.e Woolloomooloo Bay] Digital ID: 15344_a044_000033.jpg [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8595447769/]79. Pitts [i.e. Potts] Point from Domain There are more Degotardi photo's in the State Library of NSW's PXB 258 album Ebsworth Family - album of Sydney, Newcastle & Bathurst views by various photographers - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=448950 - which may lead to the attribution of more photos.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wondering what made you think the [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nationalarchives/] photo was by Pickering? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/royalaustralianhistoricalsociety/] [see [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/]'s link] have the photo attributed to John Sharkey, dated Feb. 1871 - which makes sense as he was the Government Printing Office's photolithographic branch manager at the time (with a staff of about 7).
